@Fabrizio Montesi: I just noticed that the name "Symbol" is used for an inductive type in Mathlib.Computability.Language:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Computability/Language.html#Symbol
which is used extensively in Mathlib.Computability.ContextFreeGrammar. So it seems that we'll have to use "Alphabet" for the type variable of the alphabet in automata theory and perhaps in LTS as well, unless we want to develop our own version of those theories (which I don't see a reason for at present).

We should have that moved out of the Language file; I don't see why that file should define the notion of Symbol as intended in grammars. I'll open a thread.
But it shouldn't be a problem in the meantime: we can just add {Symbol : Type _} as an implicit parameter to our defs where it matters.

Fabrizio Montesi said:

We should have that moved out of the Language file; I don't see why that file should define the notion of Symbol as intended in grammars.

It is my fault.

Ching-Tsun Chou said:

So it seems that we'll have to use "Alphabet" for the type variable of the alphabet in automata theory

Do you mean Alphabet as a name of variable or as a name of constant?

Martin Dvořák said:

Would it be ok to move it into a 'Grammar' namespace or something like that? :-)

Martin Dvořák said:

Ching-Tsun Chou said:

So it seems that we'll have to use "Alphabet" for the type variable of the alphabet in automata theory

Do you mean Alphabet as a name of variable or as a name of constant?

I think Fabrizio prefers to use Symbol as the type variable of the alphabet in LTS and automata theory, because he finds the expression x : Symol less weird to read than x : Alphabet. Neither he nor I like to use lowercase Greek letters for type variables. In automata theory, I personally find it very hard to distinguish between α (for alphabet) and σ (for states) in all the fonts I've tried.
I personally think that while constants should have "descriptions as names", variables should have "names as names".
Whether the latter means names like T or names like David.

The problem is that ContextFreeGrammar doesn't open the Grammar namespace and Symbol isn't specific to ContextFreeGrammar only.
(not very important, but just fyi:) we're currently using Symbol, ranged over by x, in automata theory, and Label, ranged over by \mu, in LTS.
